awd_titl_txt: CIF: Medium: Anonymous Broadcasting over Networks: Fundamental Limits and Algorithms
awd_abstract_narration:
In a free society, people have the right to live without being unduly monitored or surveilled. When that right is violated, anonymity-preserving technologies can provide a safety net. Anonymity-preserving systems are specifically designed to prevent adversaries from linking users to their actions within the system; most online services today are not designed to protect anonymity.

This project studies the anonymity properties of networked systems in which users broadcast sensitive information over a network. It considers two representative applications: anonymous microblogging and cryptocurrencies. Anonymous microblogging refers to social networks where users broadcast messages over a social graph; examples include Yik Yak and Whisper. Cryptocurrencies are distributed, digital currencies that allow a community to collectively, cryptographically verify the legitimacy of transactions; Bitcoin is the most successful example. Both anonymous microblogging platforms and cryptocurrencies broadcast sensitive messages over a network and are generally perceived as systems that protect user anonymity. This project aims to understand, from first principles, the vulnerabilities of existing broadcasting protocols against statistical deanonymization attacks, and whether such attacks can be prevented by carefully designing new protocols. Additionally, the project will develop open-source implementations to demonstrate the key theory including a distributed anonymous messaging application and a lightweight upgrade to Bitcoin's networking stack. The project also includes training of graduate and undergraduate students in this important research area.

The project is conducted in three steps. The first step is model-building which extracts simple, canonical mathematical models that capture the essence of these complex systems. The second step is source detection, where an adversary performing statistical inference to deanonymize the source of a broadcast is considered, and the mathematical models from step 1 are used to analyze the vulnerability of current protocols. The final step focuses on source hiding where the aim is to design novel broadcasting and network-management protocols that give provably-optimal anonymity guarantees while maintaining high utility for the target applications.

por.por_cntn:
This project studies the anonymity properties of networked systems in which users broadcast sensitive information over a network. It considers two representative applications: anonymous microblogging and cryptocurrencies. Both anonymous microblogging platforms and cryptocurrencies broadcast sensitive messages over a network and are generally perceived as systems that protect user anonymity. This project aims to understand, from first principles, the vulnerabilities of existing broadcasting protocols against statistical deanonymization attacks, and whether such attacks can be prevented by carefully designing new protocols. 

The scope of this project evolved over the course of the grant. While we directly tackled the questions proposed in the initial proposal, we also studied other related questions, concerning the efficiency of propagation over graphs and the privacy of hiding the graph itself. 

1) Anonymous message propagation in cryptocurrency peer-to-peer networks: 

We first studied the propagation of messages over peer-to-peer networks. For example, Bitcoin enjoys a public perception of being a privacy-preserving financial system. Researchers have demonstrated deanonymization attacks that exploit the Bitcoin peer-to-peer (P2P) networking stack. In particular, the P2P network currently forwards content in a structured way that allows observers to deanonymize users by linking their transactions to the originating IP addresses. 

We first demonstrated that current message propagation protocols in cryptocurrency networks exhibit poor anonymity guarantees, both theoretically and in practice. We proposed a simple networking policy called Dandelion, which achieves nearly-optimal anonymity guarantees at minimal latency cost. The papers from this project appeared in venues including SIGMETRICS (2017, 2018), NeurIPS (2018), and Transactions on Information Theory (2018).  Dandelion was released as an open-source repository and adopted by several cryptocurrencies. 

2) Inferring properties of a private graph from transactions:

Often, the topology of a peer-to-peer (P2P) network is itself private information. We studied how adversarial nodes can use message propagation to infer properties of the network. We wrote a paper titled “Strategic latency reduction in blockchain P2P networks”, which was published at Sigmetrics (2023). Our main result shows that an agent that can make and break links can use simple algorithms to manipulate its position in a P2P network to reduce its hop distance (latency) to other nodes. We show this both theoretically and empirically on the Ethereum P2P network. Even if the agent lacks knowledge about the network topology, it can use these algorithms to form links to a target (victim) node, using only latency measurements to listen to their traffic or censor transactions. 

3) Optimizing throughput of transactions in finite-resource peer-to-peer networks under privacy constraints: 

A third topic that came out of this grant was related to understanding how to efficiently propagate digital currency over credit networks, particularly in the presence of privacy guarantees. Credit networks rely on decentralized, pairwise trust relationships (channels) to exchange money or goods. Credit networks arise naturally in many financial systems, including the recent construct of payment channel networks in blockchain systems. An important performance metric for these networks is their transaction throughput. However, (1) predicting the throughput of a credit network is nontrivial, and (2) existing privacy protections make it difficult to achieve the optimal throughput of a credit network. In this work, we studied methods for predicting the throughput of a network based on its topology and initial conditions. In parallel, we studied privacy-utility tradeoffs that arise when channel capacities are hidden due to privacy constraints. We show fundamental limits on privacy-utility tradeoffs, and propose mechanisms that achieve within a constant factor of this lower bound. These works were published in SIGMETRICS 2020 and IFIP Performance 2021. 

Broader Impacts

In terms of broader impacts, Co-PI Viswanath has created course material on blockchains (which includes some of the listed results), and made it publicly available. The course material includes labs in which students get hands-on experience working with the different layers of blockchains. This material has been widely used and adapted to courses at other universities. Co-PI Fanti has integrated the materials from this proposal into her course on Foundations of Privacy. Students learn in particular about differential privacy and statistical deanonymization attacks, including those that can deanonymize Bitcoin nodes. Some of the research funded by this grant (e.g., Dandelion) has been adopted in production by several blockchains in their networking layer. 

Summary

Overall, this grant expands our understanding of many aspects of privacy of transactions or messages flowing over graphs. Our tools primarily involve the probabilistic analysis of random processes defined over graphs. Using these tools, we studied how to infer properties of the message source, the message contents, and the graph topology itself, in applications related to cryptocurrencies, anonymous messaging, peer review, and more. Over the course of this award, we have proposed new formulations, proposed algorithms with theoretical privacy (and sometimes utility) guarantees, and implemented them in real systems. Our empirical studies have been published as open-source libraries, some of which were transitioned to production systems.
